title: Thursday's Markets:  S&P, Nasdaq Gain, but Dow Falls  ----  By Caitlin McCabe and Anna Hirtenstein
text:
The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rebounded as investors shook off concerns about mounting inflation.

Traders for months have been digesting signs that inflation is worsening amid supply-chain bottlenecks, but on Wednesday new data presented the highest figure yet. The Labor Department said the consumer-price index increased 6.2% in October year over year. That marked the quickest 12-month pace since 1990 and the fifth consecutive month of inflation above 5%.

On Thursday, however, there was evidence that investors were again taking pricing pressures in stride. The benchmark S&P 500 added 2.56 points, or 0.1%, to 4649.27, reversing direction after finishing Wednesday with its largest one-day decline in more than a month. The Nasdaq Composite gained 81.58 points, or 0.5%, to 15704.28.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 158.71 points, or 0.4%, to 35921.23. The blue-chip index was pulled down, in part, by Walt Disney's worst daily performance in more than a year.

Shares of growth and technology companies, which tend to perform poorly in an inflationary environment, helped push the S&P and Nasdaq higher. Advanced Micro Devices gained $6.14, or 4.4%, to $146.01. Nvidia added $9.31, or 3.2%, to $303.90. Netflix rose 410.67, or 1.7%, to $657.58.

Financial companies, which tend to benefit from higher interest rates, also rallied. Energy and materials stocks posted strong performances, too. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks rose 0.8%.

Wednesday's slide following the inflation data was a "well-deserved pullback" after an autumn stock-market rally that pushed the S&P 500 to a stretch of repeated records, said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist at LPL Financial. "Economic growth is still quite solid, and that's going to drive longer-term stock-market gains. We think the underlying fundamentals that got us here are still in place, and that's what investors need to keep in mind."

Even as pricing pressures remain top of mind for strategists and investors, many say they have a bullish outlook for the rest of the year.

Stocks are coming out of a strong earnings season, during which about 81% of reporting S&P 500 companies beat earnings expectations, according to FactSet data through Thursday morning.

Investors say commentary in recent earnings calls gave them confidence that many companies can navigate inflationary pressures.

In corporate news, Rivian Automotive jumped by $22.26, or 22%, to $122.99. The electric-vehicle startup made its public debut Wednesday, closing at $100.73, well above the $78 initial offering price.

Tesla lost $4.44, or 0.4%, to $1,063.51. Regulatory filings showed Elon Musk sold about $5 billion of shares in the auto maker this week. Twitter users directed the chief executive to sell 10% of his stake in the company in an online poll last weekend.

The U.S. bond market was closed for Veterans Day.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 ticked up 0.3% to a record.

Early Friday, Japan's Nikkei 225 was up 1.1%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index was up 0.5% and the Shanghai Composite was down 0.1%. U.S. stock futures was up 0.2%.
